Hi Louise,

On 5/9/07, elmoseeriksen <elmoseeriksen@...> wrote:
> I read the article via the FAQ's about how to test protected/private
>  methods with JUnit, and it works fine for non-inherited methods.
>
>  But how should i test protected inherited methods?
>  [...]
>  When testing changeNo in class B, I would like to verify that no == 3,
>   but I cannot access no or A.getNo since they are not returned in
>  object.getClass().getDeclaredFields() or
>  object.getClass().getDeclaredMethods() when called on class B.
>
>  I could put all my tests in the same package as the classes being
>  tested, but I would like to avoid that.

You simply need to do the "getDeclaredMethods()" recursively for all
of the parent classes.

Here's an example of how you might go about doing that:

http://svn.laughingpanda.org/svn/beaninject/trunk/src/main/java/org/laughingpanda/beaninject/impl/Accessor.java

(or  http://tinyurl.com/2hy92t  )

Lasse
